awd_titl_txt: Towards an improved understanding of tidal turbine dynamics in a turbulent marine environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Renewable energy technologies offer the promise of non-polluting and sustainable alternatives to fossil and nuclear-fueled power plants. The objective of this research project is to better understand the interactions between a tidal turbine and the surrounding fluid environment. Tidal turbines are a relatively new class of renewable energy devices that convert the motion of flowing water in rivers or tides into energy.  This research is focused on addressing several outstanding scientific challenges that need to be overcome so that these novel devices can be developed and deployed.  In addition to the scientific discoveries, the educational component of this research project involves training the next generation of engineers and professionals through research, teaching, and outreach activities. The outreach component involves partnering with Lehigh University?s Office of Outreach and Northampton Community College in the STAR (Students That Are Ready) program, which targets economically and academically disadvantaged and/or at-risk 8th to 12th grade students.  The social impact of the long-term success of tidal turbine technology is significant. In addition to the continental United States, commercialization of these technologies may directly impact a major fraction of the world population as the majority of large population centers are located either close to major rivers or coastlines.
 
The experimental design in this research project is motivated by the need to couple near and far wake physics to turbine performance at elevated levels of free-stream turbulence. Turbulence generation techniques using active grids are being used to mimic hydraulic and natural in-stream conditions. Diagnostics include a reaction torque-thrust sensor for system analysis and time-resolved stereo particle image velocimetry for flow-field measurements. A detailed understanding of the evolution of the wake is vital when considering design of a tidal farm (similar to wind farms). Designing an optimal farm layout in rivers is challenging as the useful zone for power extraction may be restricted to a small footprint due to navigational requirements.  Existing engineering analysis do not fully capture the non-linear interactions that arise due to such closely packed layouts or the associated environmental impact. To enhance the scientific impact, the new data sets are being made available to the scientific community to allow validation and verification of advanced computational fluid dynamics models of flow around tidal turbines.

por.por_cntn:
The overall objective of the research program was to enhance our limited understanding of the interactions between a horizontal-axis tidal turbine and its surrounding environment. Tidal turbines are a new class of renewable energy devices that tap the kinetic energy of the flowing water in rivers or tides. In these environments, the approach flow contains elevated free-stream turbulence levels and large coherent structures. The tide produces a deformable free surface that, in turn, creates a blockage. The combination of turbulence and blockage affects the performance and structural loading of the turbine as well as the signature of the downstream wake. This project investigated the unique coupling between the flow, the device and the free surface by a detailed experimental campaign in controlled laboratory settings. The funding allowed the development of the *first* active grid turbulence generator in a water tunnel in the United States. The Tidal Turbulence Test Facility (T3F) has been calibrated to operate at elevated free-stream turbulence levels (10-30%). It can recreate shear flow profiles observed in tidal estuaries using an innovative combination of static and rotating winglets and operating protocols developed during the project's duration. The experimental campaign focused on studying tidal turbine response and near-wake evolution for three different test cases:

Blockage and Free-surface Effect: Flow acceleration near the turbine rotation plane was attributed to blockage offered by the rotor, wake, and free surface deformation. In addition, particle image velocimetry was carried out in the turbine near-wake using time- and phase-averaged techniques to understand the mechanism responsible for the variation of power coefficient with rotational speed and free surface proximity. Slower wake propagation for higher rotational velocities and increased asymmetry in the wake with increasing free surface proximity were observed. Improved performance at high rotational speed was attributed to enhanced wake blockage, and performance enhancement with free surface proximity was due to the additional blockage effects caused by the free surface deformation.

Elevated Freestream Turbulence Effect: The research measured the performance and near wake characteristics of a laboratory scale (1:20 ratio) tidal turbine in elevated levels of free-stream turbulence (12%) and compared them to observations in an undisturbed quasi-laminar flow (2.2%). The findings revealed that elevated levels of turbulence have a significant impact on the load fluctuations acting on the turbine, increasing the standard deviation of the power coefficient by a factor of 4.5. Such large load fluctuations have the potential to severely impact the operation and longevity of tidal turbines and their components, underscoring the practical implications of this research. The integral length scale contours illustrate the evolution of length scales in the wake of the rotor. Length scales calculated in the rotor wake at elevated turbulence levels were noticeably larger and less uniform than those calculated in the quasi-laminar flow. Elevated turbulence was observed to facilitate a quicker recovery of the wake velocity deficit. Based on the available energy estimations in the turbine wake, the flow recovery in elevated turbulence at X/D = 4 was ~37%, nearly twice the corresponding value in the quasi-laminar flow case. This has significant implications for the farm-scale deployment of tidal turbines, suggesting that in high ambient turbulence levels, tidal turbines can be packed more closely than the downstream spacing typically recommended based on analytical wake models.

The project partially supported five Ph.D. students. Three finished their Ph.D's during the project, and the other two were in the advanced stages of their PhD studies when writing this outcomes report. Two students participated in semester-long internships with Verdant Power through support from the NSF INTERN program. The PI has developed a module on Marine Energy for a Renewable Energy Course. This is a cross-listed course for undergraduate seniors and graduate students. This module is being used to provide enhanced educational experiences to our seniors. The PI also coached a team of Middle Schoolers (Grades 6 - 8) from a local school district. Students were introduced to concepts of aerodynamics (flying) with demo experiments on lift and drag using gliders made of balsa wood. In addition, the PI coached another team representing Pennsylvania in the National Science Olympiad National competition in East Lansing, MI. The team, coached by the PI, won the gold medal in the wind power category among 60 schools participating nationwide.
